bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawêh ê-misâk ôtênaw ayîsiyiniwak êh-wîkicik , pêyak okimâw otânisa miyosiyiwa . Once upon a time in a big town where people dwelt, a certain chief had a beautiful daughter.
piciwak kahkiyaw . All moved camp.
pêyak piko mîkiwâhp cimatêw , êh-nakatiht pêyak kisêyiniw , êkwah owîkimâkanah , nôtokêsiwah . Only one tipi was left standing, where an old man was abandoned, together with the old woman, his wife.
êkwah nîso iskwêsisah ayâwêwak . And they had two girls.
matokahpihk wîkiwak ôki kâ-nakatihcik . On the deserted camp-site they dwelt who had been abandoned.

êh-wâpaniyik , papâmohtêwak ôki iskwêsisak , êh-otinahkik oskanah , êh-pakâhtâcik , ê-môsahkinahkik matokâhpihk , êh-mîcimâpôhkêcik , êkosi pikoh êy-isi-mîcisocik . In the morning those girls walked about, taking up bones, which they boiled. Picking up things from the deserted camp and making soup of them was the only way they got anything to eat.
êkwah kîtahtawêh nâpêsisak , êy-ispatinâyik , nâtakâm ohci matâwisiw nâpêsis pêyak ; Then at one time some boys, from over a hill, from the north, a boy came into sight,

êkwah pêyak itêy êh-pahkisimohk isi kotak mina êyako nâpêsis , cacêkahkwânah êh-takonahkik , ispatinâhk êy-itohtêcik . and another one, also a boy, from the west, and they carried throwing-sticks in their hands, and walked to a rise in the land. LB on {cacêkahkwânah}: The word {cikahkwân}: “lance,” (plural {-ah}, or reduplicated {cacêkahkwânah}) is used also of small darts with which boys played a game: one threw his dart so that it stuck upright in the ground, and the opponent tried to throw his so as to split the other. The same word in animate gender (plural {-ak}) is used of the girls' and women's gambling toy which consists (seen on Star Blanket Reserve) of four slabs of wood shaped like a knife-blade with surfaces slightly convex, and measuring perhaps 8 by 3 inches. On one side of two slabs are bear-tracks; on one side of the other two, weasel-tracks. The four slabs are grasped in one hand and tossed; the throw counts according to the combination of bear-tracks, weasel-tracks, and blanks that turn up.
êh-âmaciwê-cikahkwêt kotak mina , kâ-pimakotêyik cikahkwân . When one of them, the second one, threw a throwing-stick up the hill, [sic]
wâpahtam awa nistam kâh-âcimak . and it sped through the air, the one of whom first I spoke, saw it.
mîna kîhtwâm cikâhkwêw , kotak mîna kâ-pimakotêyik . Again he threw a dart, and it, too, flew through the air.
awa nistam k-âcimak nâpêsis âmaciwêw , ocikahkwân ê-nâtahk . The boy of whom I spoke first went up the hill to fetch his dart.

seg.gloss: “Yoho! So here he is!

p.seg: wîh-nitawi-wîwiw , kitikawih ! ôma k-êtât awa pahkisimohk k-ôhtohtêt . To be sure, ‘He is going off to take a wife,’ was said of you!” said he who had come from the west.
hââ ! namoya ! kiy êtok ôma ê-wîh-wîwiyan ! itêw awa nâtakâm k-ôhtohtêt . “Oh no! I daresay it is you, really, who mean to take a wife!” said he who came from the north.

êkwah ,
kintawi-wîwih ! itêw . But, “You were going off to take a wife!” he told him.
êkwah nîhtaciwêwak , matokâhpihk êh-itohtêcik . Then they descended the hill and went to the deserted camp-site.
pêyak namoya wâpiskisiw . One was not white.
namoya mwâsih pîkiskwêw êyako . this one did not speak much.
êkwah awa kotak kîskwêw , êh-osâmitonêt , êh-pîkiskwêskit . But the other one was silly and talked too much and was a babbler.
hâw , êkotah anih cimatwâtotân ! itwêw awa k-ôsâmitonêt . “Now then, right here let us play throwing-stick!” said the talkative one.
ma-mêtawêwak êkotah . They continued to play there.
kîtahtawê ôk âwâsisak iskwêsisak kâ-pêhtawâcik nâpêsisah êh-tâtwêwitamiyit . Presently those children, those girls, heard the noise which the lads were making there.

seg.q: hêy , nôhtâh , kêhcinâ ê-kî-wêpinihcik ôtah awâsisak nîso kâ-cimatwâtocik .
seg.gloss: “Oh, father, surely those two children who are playing with throwing-sticks have been abandoned here.

seg.q: kêhcinâh ê-kîh-wêpinihcik êwakonik mîna , kiyânaw mîna kâ-wêpinikawiyahk !
seg.gloss: Surely they have been abandoned, just as we have!”
“Yes, children.
So put the lodge in order at the other side of the fire.
Go play with them, each of you with one.
That will keep you from being lonesome, if you play with them.

p.seg: ntawi-ntomihkok , itâwak ôk îskwêsisak . Go invite them,” those girls were told.
mton êh-otâkosiniyik , itohtêwak ôk îskwêsisak . Late in the afternoon those girls went there.
kâ-pîkiskwêskicik êkotôwahk awa aw ômisimâw . Of those who are talkative, such was the elder girl.
aw ôsîmimâw namoya mwâsi pîkiskwêw . The younger was not given to much speech.
nêki mina nâpêsisak aw ôscêsimâs kâw-osâmitônêsit . Of those boys, too, it was the elder who was a prattler.

êkosi êw-otihtâcik ,
nîkinâhk kiwî-pêy-itohtânâwâw ta-wîci-ma-mêtawêmitâhk ! So, when they came to where the others were, “You are to come to our house and play with us!”
wâpam nâha ka-wîh-wîwiyan ! itwêw awa kaw-osâmicônisit ; “Look at the girl you are going to marry!” said the prattler;

seg.gloss: “Yah, do not forget you came here to take a wife!

p.seg: ntawi-nahâhkapi ! itêw osîma . Go stay with your wife's people!” he said to his younger brother.
kiy ôma kâ-wîh-wîwiyan , namoya niya , itêw awa kâ-kiyâmêwisit . “But it is you are planning to take a wife, not I,” the bashful one answered him.
êhag ! kitikowâw awa ! itêw awa k-ôsâmitônisit . “Yes! Now he has told you!” the prattler said to them.
êkos îsi kîwêpahtâwak ôk îskwêsisak . Then the girls ran back home.
êkotah ay-ayâwak . They all stayed there.
nâh-nipâwak êkotah , pâh-pêyak êh-wîhpêmâcik ôh îskwêsisah . [no translation]

kîtahtawê awa , iskwâhtêmihk êh-cimatwâtocik ,
hâw , pihêwokas ! wîhêw osîma ; Then at one time, as they played with throwing-sticks by the door, “Now then, Partridge-Claw!” said the one, calling his junior by name;

seg.gloss: “Whichever is beaten will drive in the buffalo.

seg.q: kê-wâpahk , ôma kayâsi-pîhtokahân êkotah ta-pîhtokêpayiwak mostoswak .
seg.gloss: Tomorrow let us make the buffalo run into this old buffalo-pound here.

p.seg: osâm nôhtêhkatêw kimanâcimâkan , mîcimâpoy piko êh-mîcicik , itêw . Our father-in-law is suffering too much from hunger, what with their eating nothing but soup,” he said to him.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” the other answered him.
cimatwâtôwak . They pitched their throwing sticks.
awa pihêwokas kîsiyawâw . Partridge-Claw was beaten.
pikontah sâkowêw awa kâ-kîskwêt . The babbler gaily whooped.

seg.gloss: “I have beaten him!

p.seg: êkwah wiyah kê-nâcipahât ! itêw . Now he will be the one to drive in buffalo!” he said of the other.

êkosi ê-kawisimocik owîkimâkanah ,
êkâ wiya kita-paspâpiwak kôhtâwiy kikâwiy , kêkway pêhtahkwâwi ; Then, when they went to bed, he said to his wife, “Let not your father and your mother peek out from the lodge, when they hear anything;

seg.gloss: I am going to drive in buffalo.
Be sure to tell them.

seg.q: kîspin êkâ paspâpitwâwi , pôni-pêhtâkwahki iyikohk , ta-wayawîwak kôhtâwiy kikâwiy ;
seg.gloss: If they do not peek out, then, when the noise ceases, your father and mother are to come out of the lodge;

p.seg: k-êtohtêwak pîhtokahânihk , itêw owîkimâkana . they will go to the pound,” he told his wife.
êkosi kêkâc êh-wâpaniyik , sipwêhtêw aw âwâsis kâ-kiyâmêwisit . Accordingly, just before dawn, the bashful boy went away.
êkwah wâhyaw êh-ayât , wâpaniyiw , êh-nâcipahât . When he had gone far, day broke, and he drove buffalo.
êkwah mostoso-mêya otinam misahkamik , ê-nâh-nawayôstât . He took a great amount of buffalo-dung, and laid it in little heaps in a row.

êkwah ômis îtwêw :
êhyêêêy ! Then he said, “Hey hey heyey!”
êh-itwêt , kâ-pasikôyit mostoswah misahkamik . When he gave this cry, great numbers of buffalo rose from the ground.
êhêêê hêy hêy hêy ! êkos îtwêw . “Heyeyeyey hey hey hey!” he cried. LB on {êhêêê}: This and similar calls are made with lip-rounding at the end.
êkos âti-sipwêpayiyiwa . Thereupon they ran off.
kîwêhtahêw misahkamik . He brought a great herd with him.
kîtahtawê ê-kîksêpâyâyik , nawac kêkâc êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , wâ-wâstahikâniwiw . Presently, as morning passed and it was nearing noon, the waving of signals began.

k-êtwêyit ayîsiyiniwah pêhtawêw ,
mistiminihkok atimwak , êkâ kit-ôyôyôcik ! itwêw awa kâ-matwê-têpwêt , ispih ê-matwêh-askatâhk . He heard people calling, “Hold the dogs, lest they bark!” so cried the one who called out directions while the herd was awaited.

êkoyikohk pêhtawêwak ayîsiyiniwah misahkamik , konitah atimwah k-ôyôyit ôtah matokahpihk , êkwah ê-sâkôwêwiht , ê-pîhtokêpayiyit mostoswah . Then he heard a great crowd of men, and dogs baying everywhere in that deserted camp, and loud whooping as though of their fellow-campers, as the buffalo ran into the enclosure.

hêy , nôhtâh ,
êkây ôhci paspâpit ! êkosi kîh-itwêw kinahâhkisîm ! itwêw awa iskwêsis . “Now, father, ‘Let him at no time peek out!’ said your son-in-law!” thus spoke that girl.

êkwah awa kotak nâpêsis k-ôsâmitonit ,
nâ ! mâcikôttak ta-paspâpinâniwiw ! And that other boy, the talkative one, “Nonsense! Let them look out at a sight worth seeing!
êsi-mihcêticik ayîsiyiniwak ta-wâpamâwak ! itwêw awa nâpêsis . Let them see how many people there are!” said that boy.

êkwah awa iskwêw , mwêhci wâh-paspâpiyici onâpêma , wâh-wâpamâyici ôhi kâ-tâtwêwitamiyit , miciminêw onâpêma awa nôtokêsiw . But that woman, whenever her husband wanted to peep and see the people who were making all the noise, then just in time the old woman would hold back her husband.
ôki wiya iskwêsisak wâpamêwak ayîsiyiniwa mîn âtimwa matokahpihk êh-papâmipahtâyit . But the girls could see the people and the dogs running hither and thither about the deserted camp.
êkosi pêyak ê-iskohiht mostos , pikonta sâkôwêwak ayîsiyiniwak . Then, when only one buffalo was left, the people whooped everywhere.
pêhtawêwak ôki kêhtê-ayak . The old people heard them.
mahtih ! miyâmay ôma ayîsiyiniwak ! itêyihtam awa aw îskwêw . “I do wonder! Surely these must be people!” thought she, the woman.
iskwâhtêmihk ohci paspâpiw : She peeped out through the door:

kontah pîhtokahânihk pikonta kâ-pikihtêyik , mostoso-yêhyêwin êh-pikihtawêtâmoyit mostoswah , ispimihk êh-itakotêyik , kontah k-ôhpwêhâyit nanâtohk pisiskiwah tahtoh kâ-piponihêwiyit , pîhtokahânihk , ohci kiyikaw mahîhkanah , nanatôhk mahîhkanah , matokahpihk êh-ohc-îkatêpahtâyit . from all over the buffalo-pound smoke was rising into the air, the steaming breath of buffalo rising into the atmosphere, and at the same time all kinds of animals, as many as stay through the winter, came forth from the pound, all kind of wolves, every kind of wolf, and ran offside and away from the deserted camp.
kîwêw awa nâpêsis . The boy came home.
ayis nama kêkway ihtakoniyiw . Thre was simply nothing left.
mahyakosiw , ômanâcimâkanah êh-mahyakôhikot . His spell had been broken; his parent-in-law had spoiled his luck.
êêh ! pihyêwokas êh-nêpêwisit , êh-askôtawiskât êh-âta-nâcipahât ! itêw ; “Yaha, Partridge-Claw is coming empty-handed and ashamed, for all his buffalo driving!” he said to him;

seg.gloss: “Let us play again.

p.seg: awiyak kîsiyâhcih , kita-nâcipahâw , itwêw . Whichever is beaten, let him fetch buffalo,” he said.
â , tâpwê cimatwâtôwak . Accordingly, they played throwing-stick.
kîsiyawâw awa k-ôsâmitônisit . The prattler was beaten.
mitoni kîksêpâ sipwêhtêw . Very early in the morning he set out.

kotak êkwah ôma paskwâw , itah mostoso-mêyah kâ-kîh-ôhtinahk awa kotak nâpêsis , êkotah ohtinam mostoso-mêyah , êh-nah-nawayôstât . Then on that other stretch of prairie, there where the other boy had taken buffalo-dung, from there he now took buffalo-dung, laying it in a row.
êwako mina pêyakwaniyiw êh-tôtahk . This one did the same as the other had done.
êhyêêêw ! êh-itwêt , pôtêh mostoswah pasikôyîwa misahkamik . “Heyeyey!” he cried, and there, a great herd of buffalo rose to their feet.

êkwah awa iskwêsis ,
nôhtâ , nêkâ , pêyakwâ piko kâ-kitahamâkoyêk kinahâhkisîm êkâ ta-paspâpiyêk . Then that girl, “Father, mother, once and for all time your son-in-law has forbidden you to peer out.

seg.gloss: When that noise begins at the corral, do you, father hold back my mother.
Plainly it was she who spoiled things for her son-in-law.

seg.q: mitonih pôni-pêhtâkwahkih , êkoyikohk takosihkih ôyâ kinahâhkisîm , kika-nâtênâwâw wiyâsah .
seg.gloss: When the sound has entirely died away, then, after your son-in-law who has now gone away returns, then you will fetch the meat.
Do not try to see things before that time.

p.seg: iyikohk takosihki kinahâhkisîmiwâw , êkoyikohk kik-êtohtânâwâw pîhtokahânihk , itêw ôhtâwiya min ôkâwiya . Only when your son-in-law arrives here are you to go to the pound,” she told her father and her mother.
kîtahtawê wâ-wâstahikâniwiw . Presently the signals were waved.

oskinîkîtik , ntaw-âskatâk ! k-êtwêyit ayîsiyiniwa , pikonita kâ-pêhtâkwaniyik matokahpihk , tâpiskôc mîkiwâhpah êh-ayâyikih , ispih ê-pîhtokêpayiyit mostoswah , kahkiyaw ê-nipahimiht . “Young men! Go lie in wait!” cried the people, and all over the abandoned camp-site the noise began, just as if the tents were yet there, and then the buffalo came running into the corral and were all killed.

iyât-âwa-pîhtokêci awa nâpêsis ,
nâ , mâcikôttak ta-wâpamâwak ayîsiyiniwak ê-mihcêticik ! iyât-îtwêci , nam âwiya paspâpiyiwa omanâcimâkana . Even though he, that boy, said, “Nonsense, it is worth seeing, the crowd of people!” yet neither of his parents-in-law peeked out.
wiyawâw wiya wâpamêwak ayîsiyiniwah . But they themselves could see the people.

êkwah ôtêh pîhtokahânihk êh-matwê-wîhimiht ôhtâwîwâwa ,
awa kiya omostoso-mêy , kiya kinahâhkisîm pêsiwêw mostoswah ! Then, right there from the buffalo-pound they heard their father being called by name, “It is you, Buffalo-Dung, whose son-in-law is bringing the buffalo!
êwakô ohci êh-wiyinot k-ôh-miyitân ! êh-itiht , That is why I am giving you the fattest one!” he was told,
ay-apiw ; namoya wîh-paspâpiw . but he stayed right where he was; he would not peer out.

êkwah ôhi matokâhpihk ayîsiyiniwak êh-wâh-wîhimiht ,
awa kiya , omostoso-mêy ! wiyâs kit-ôtinahk , mitoni kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah êh-wîhimiht , êkwah matokahpihk êh-tatwêwitamiyit awâsisah , pêhtawêwak ôki kêhtê-ayak . Then when the people who had lived in that now deserted camp were called, now one, now another, by name, “This one is for you, buffalo-Dung!” (meaning that he was to take the meat), when all the people, to the last one, were called by name, and when even the children were noising about in the abandoned camp, that old couple heard them all.
ôki wiya otawâsimisah wayawîtimihk ay-ayâyiwa , asici onahâhkisîmiwâwa . But his children were outside, with the old people's son-in-law.
kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-takohtêyit onahâhkisîmiwâwa . Presently they heard their son-in-law arrive.

seg.q: hâw , êkwah wiyâsah kit-âsah kit-âwâtâwak kôhtâwiy kikâwiy , mîna ta-mîciyêk kitaw-otinahkik .
seg.gloss: “There now, now let your father and mother go fetch the meats, and let them take some for you to eat.

p.seg: kahkiyaw matokahpihk têsipicikanah k-âyâkih , êkotah kit-ât-âkotâwak wiyâsah , mîn ôtah kitêsipicikaniwâhk tân âna êh-wiyinoyit , êyakonih kit-ôtinêwak , wiyâsah kitaw-otinahkik , ta-mîcicik ! itwêw awa nâpêsis k-ôsâmicônisit ; On all the drying-frames that are on the camp-site let them hang the meats, and for this drying-frame of yours let them take the fattest one, to provide meat for them to eat!” said the boy who was a prattler;

seg.q: êkosi tôtahkwâwi , êkâ paspâpitwâwi , tahk êkosi kit-êsi-miyopayiw .
seg.gloss: “If they do this way and do not peep, things will always go as well as this.
But if they peep, things will not go well.

seg.q: kiyâm awa piyêwokas nâcipahâci , pêyakwan kit-êspayiw , êkâ paspâpitwâwi kôhtâwiy kikâwiy mîna .
seg.gloss: Even if Partridge-Claw here drives buffalo, things will go just as well, if only your father and your mother do not try to look.

seg.q: nîswâw kî-nâcipahâci pihêwokas , êkoyikohk êtokê ta-kîh-nîpinisinâniwiw .
seg.gloss: By the time Partridge-Claw has had two turns at driving in buffalo, there will be enough, I guess, for a stay over the summer.
You will have a big supply of meat.
This Partridge-Claw is not really a child.

p.seg: niya mina , êh-kitimâkêyimitâhk , êh-nôhtêhkatêyêk , k-ôh-pêy-itohtêyâhk kîkiwâhk , itêw ; And I, too; because we felt sorry for you when you were starving, is why we came to your dwelling,” he told her;

seg.q: wîhtamôwâhkan kôhtâwiy kikâwiy : mina wâpahkih ta-nâcipahâw pihêwokas .
seg.gloss: “Tell your father and mother: tomorrow again Partridge-Claw is to drive buffalo.

seg.q: êkotah ohci nânitaw nêwo-tipiskâk mîna ta-nâcipahâw .
seg.gloss: Some four days after that he is to drive them again.

p.seg: piyisk mistahi kik-âyânâwâw mîciwin , itêw owîkimâkanah . In the end you will have a big supply of food,” he told his wife.
êkosi êkwah papâh-ma-mêtawêwak ôk âwâsisak . Then those children went about playing.
kîtahtawê otinamwak misâskwatwa pâh-pêyak . Then at one time each of them took a stick of saskatoon willow.
pîhtokatâwak wîkiwâhk , êkwah êh-astawâtahkik . They brought them into the lodge and put feathers on them, to make arrows.
miywâsiniyiwa . They were pretty.
waniskânikanihk apasôhk êkotah tahkopitamwak . They tied them to the master-pole by which the tent is raised.

ômis îtwêw awa k-ôsâmicônisit :
nîtim , êkâya wîhkâc otinamok ôki ; Thus spoke the prattler: “Sister-in-law, do you and the others never take these;
osâm sâkihtâw nîpisisah awa pihêwokas , itêw . Partridge-Claw is very particular about my arrows,” he told her.
pêhtamwak ôki kêhtê-ayak . The old-folks heard this.

seg.q: â , êyakonik k-ôh-pimâtisiyahk , êh-tôtamâkoyâhk mîciwin , nitawâsimisitik !
seg.gloss: “Now, it is to them we owe our lives, since they have provided food for us, children!

p.seg: êkâya wîhkâc sâminamok ahpôh ninahâhkisîmak wîpisisiwâwa , wiy ê-sâkihtâcik ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . Never so much as touch my sons-in-laws' arrows, since they are particular about them!” said the old man.
êkwah wiyâpaniyik , nâcipahâw aw âwâsis pêyak kâ-kiyâmêwisit . Then, the next morning, the child who was bashful went buffalo driving.
pêyakwaniyiw êh-tôtahkik . They always did it in the same way.
pîhtokêpayiyiwa mostoswa . The buffalo ran into the pound.
pêyakwaniyiw êh-tatwêwitamiyit ayîsiyiniwa awâsisah mîna , êkây ê-wîh-paspâpicik . Even as before, the people and the children made their din, and they did not peer out.

kahkiyaw kwayâci-wiyanihcikâsoyiwa ôhi mostoswah . sôskwâc kâ-kapê-kîsik êh-âwatâcik wiyâsah ôki kêhtê-ayak . All the buffalo were skinned and cut up for them beforehand, so that without delay the old couple could set about fetching in meat day after day.

êkosi matokâhpihk êh-nakatamoht ôhi têsipicikanah mitonih ê-sâkaskinahtâcik iyikohk , pôyôwak ôk âwâsisak . Then, when the drying scaffolds that had been left on the abandoned site were all full, the children ceased.

êkwah ômis îtwêw awa k-ôsâmicônisit nâpêsis :
nîtim , asaminân . Then the boy who was a prattler spoke: “Sister-in-law, give us food.

seg.gloss: Give us provisions for the way.

p.seg: mâskôc kîtahtawê namoya nka-takohtânân , êkotah ta-mîciyâhk , itwêw awa nâpêsis k-ôsâmicônisit . Perhaps some time we shall not get home; let us have food to eat off there,” said the boy who was a prattler.

tâpwê miyâwak kahkêwakwah mînah wiyinwah mînah otakisiya ê-sakâpihkâtamoht , t-êsi-nayôhtahkik . Accordingly, they were given pieces of dried meat and of fat meat and tripe, nicely wrapped into a bundle for them to carry on their backs.
êkos êh-tôtâhcik , êkwah wayawîwak kîksêpâ . When this had been done for them, then early in the morning they went out of the tipi.

seg.q: hâw , pihêwokas , nôhtêhkatêwak ôki ôtah awah k-ôh-picit okimâw .
seg.gloss: “Now, Partridge-Claw, that chief who moved away from this camp and his people are starving.
Let us go there.

p.seg: kohkominaw ntaw-âsamâtân , itêw . Let us go give our grandmother food,” he said to the other.
êhag , itwêw awa nâpêsis . “Very well,” said that boy.
ohpîwak , nayêwâc êh-pimakocihkik . They rose from the ground, flying through the air.
mitonih êw-otâkosiniyik , otihtamwak mîkiwâhpah êh-mihcêniyikih . Late in the afternoon they reached the place where there were many tents.
êkwâh ôki iskwêsisak pîkiskâtêwak onâpêmiwâwa , êkây êh-pêhtawâcik itah kita-tâtwêwêtamiyit . Meanwhile those girls felt lonely for their husbands, when they did not hear them at their noisy play.
êkwah nêkih itah êh-sakâyik êkotah pakicîwak . But those others alighted in a grove of trees.

seg.gloss: “Now, Partridge-Claw, I have no confidence in your powers.

p.seg: niya mahtih nka-ntawâpamâwak ôk âwâsisak , itêw owîcêwâkanah . Let me be the one to go see those children,” he said to his comrade.
ohpîw , êh-pihêwit . He flew up in the form of a partridge.
mîtosihk twêhôw . He settled on a poplar tree.
êy ! âstamitik ! awa pihêw ! itwêwak awâsisak . “Hey! Come here! See this partridge!” cried the children.
pimwêwak . They shot arrows at it.
iyâta-pimohci awa pihêw , ohpihâw . Although the partridge was shot at, it flew up.
kisiwâk twêhôw . Close by it settled again.
êkos ôk âwâsisak nôsôskawêwak mihcêt . So the children chased it hard.
kîtahtawê wâhyaw êh-itohtahât , sôskwâc ohpahôw . Presently, when he had drawn them off a long ways, suddenly he flew up.
itêh kâ-kîh-nakatât owîcêwâkanah , êkotah twêhôw . There where he had left his comrade, he came down.
kâw âwâsisiwiw . He turned back into a child.
êkwah mitihtêwak ôh âwâsisah . Then they followed those children's tracks.
kêkâ-tipiskâyiw . It was almost night.
êyikohk êh-pê-kiwêcik ôki awâsisak , nâh-nakiskawêwak . When those children were coming home, they began meeting them one after another.
kwahkonikwak , êh-kipiskawâcik . The children pushed them over and blocked their way.
nâway ayâwak ; ayis kont îtê si-kwahkonikwak . They were in the rear; for at every point the others pushed them over.

êh-âta wâh-pasikôtwâwi , kotakah êh-kwâhkonikocik , piyisk nâway ayâwak . Whenever they tried to get on their feet, others pushed them over, until they were in the rear. LB on {êh-âta}: Probably read {iyâta-}; in either case we have a verb-form which is not finished, but is re-commenced in the {wâh-} of the next word.
êh-ati-tipiskâyik , wâpahtamwak nôtokêsiwah wîkisiyiw , wîstêpahkwawikamik . When night came on, they saw an old woman's little tent, a tipi of old bits of leather.

seg.gloss: “This is our grandmother's dwelling, Partridge-Claw.
Let us go in.
Let us sleep here.

p.seg: namoya ta-kih-kîwêyahk anohc , itwêwak . We cannot get home today,” they said.
êhag , itwêw awa kâ-kiyâmêwisit . “Very well,” said the bashful one.

êkwah êh-pîhtokêcik ,
hê , nôhkô ! ôtah nka-cimatwâtonân kitiskwâhtêmihk ! Then, as they entered, “Hey, grandmother! Let us play with our throwing-sticks here by your doorway!”
êhag , nôsisimisitik ! itikwak . “Yes, my grandchildren!” she said to them.
êkwah êôkotah ma-mêtawêwak , êh-cimatwâtocik . Then they continued to play there with their throwing-sticks.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik poyôwak . At last, when it was dark, they ceased.
êkwah nêki iskwêsisak , êkâ ê-kîh-nipâcik , kitâpahtamwak ôh âcosisah nîso . Meanwhile those girls yonder, who had not gone to sleep, looked at those two arrows.
waskawîmakaniyiwa . The things were moving.
kitâpahtamwak ôk îskwêsisak . The girls watched them.

êkwah nêki nâpêsisak ,
hêy , nôsisimitik , êkwah ninôhtêhkwasin . And the boys off there, “Hey, my grandchildren, now I am sleepy.

seg.gloss: Go and sleep now.
Go home.
I am sleepy.”

p.seg:
êkwah awa k-ôsâmicônisit ômis îtêw :
nôhkô , namoya nânitaw nika-kîh-nipânân , êh-itwêt . Then the prattler said to her, “Grandmother, there will not be any place for us to sleep.”
ôki âsay nipâwak nêtêh nêma kêhtê-ayak . Off back yonder that old couple was already asleep.

êkwah ôki iskwêsisak k-ôtinahkik oh âcosisah , êh-waskawimakaniyikih , kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahkik êh-pîkiskwêyit , ôh âcosisah êh-pîkiskwêmakahkih . And as those girls picked up the arrows which were moving, suddenly they heard someone speak, as if those arrows were speaking.
awa wêwîpisisit tânisi êh-itwêt , êkotah pîkiskwêw wîpisisihk . Whatever the owner of the arrow said, he spoke in the arrow there.

seg.gloss: “Big sister, this is great, come here!

seg.q: nitohtawâtânik nîtim êkwah kîtim tânisi êtwêcik !
seg.gloss: Let us listen to my brother-in-law and to your brother-in-law to hear what they say!”

p.seg: êkosi ôhi êh-itwêmakahki acosisah , itwêyiwa . So now, whatever those arrows said, the others were saying.
êkwah nitohtawâwak , wâhyaw êh-ayâcik . And they listened to them, though they were far away.

êkwah awa nôtokêsiw k-êtât osisima ,
nôhkô , namoya nânitaw wîhkâc niwîkihkêmonân , têpiyâhk êy-ayâsô-wîkihkêmoyâhk . And when that old woman had thus spoken to her grandchildren, “Grandmother, we never stay anywhere with people, but pay at most a little visit here and there.
tânêhk ôma , nôhko , êkâ k-oh-mîcisoyin ? itêw ôhkoma . How is it, grandmother that you do not eat?” he asked his grandmother.

seg.q: hêy , nôsisi , namoya oma mamiywê awiyak êh-mîcisot , êh-nôhtêhkatêhk ôma .
seg.gloss: “Alas, grandchild mine, no one at all eats here, for here is a famine.
But surely you know this.
I shall befriend my grandchildren.

p.seg: nôsisimitik , êwakw âna nipâkêhkêk , otanâskâniyiwa êh-isiwêpinâyit , ta-npâkêcik . My grandsons, use this to sleep on,” and she tossed them her sleeping-mat, for them to sleep on.

hâ , nôhkô , aw âwa wiya pihêwokas êh-pê-ntaw-asamisk ! ôhi itêwak , êh-miyâcik kâhkêwakwa mîna wiyinwa . “Well, grandmother, but this Partridge-Claw here has come to give you food!” they said to her, and gave her pieces of dried and of fat meats.

seg.gloss: “Thank you, my grandsons.

seg.q:
ôtah awah okimâw otânisah ,
awiyak nta-minahtâci ôma ntôtênaw , êwakoh nk-ônahâhkisîmin , êh-itwêt ,
seg.gloss: Now, the chief here, concerning his daughter, ‘If anyone kills game for my town here, him I shall take for my son-in-law,’ he has said,

seg.q: pêyak âta âskaw wâh-wîhkâc nipahêw okwâskwêpayihôsah ; mâka namoya kih-têpahotôwak ayîsiyiniwak .
seg.gloss: but, though from time to time one or another kills a deer, yet the people do not get enough to go round.
seg.note: CHECK: {kih-têpahotôwak}. Is this a new TA {kîh-têpêyiht-âwak}?

p.seg: osâm apisîs , êh-mihcêtihk , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw ; It is too little, what with the great number of them,” said the old woman;

seg.gloss: “Now, grandson, I want to lie down.

p.seg: itâp êkotah nka-mîcison , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . Now I shall be able to sleep,” said the old woman.
nipâwak êkwah nêki iskwêsisak . The girls off yonder had gone to sleep.
acosisah tahkonamwak . They held the arrows in their hands.
êh-itwêmakaniyikih , ntohtawêwak onâpêmiwâwa . When the things spoke, they listened to their husbands.

seg.gloss: “Hey, Partridge-Claw, do you now go courting!
Go court this chief's daughter!”

p.seg: hâ , mâka mîn êcik âni wâ-mikoskâtisiyan ! itêw awa ostêsah . “Ha, so it seems you are again making trouble!” he said to his elder brother.

seg.q: hâ , wiy ê-sâkwêyimoyan , kiyâm ici niya !
seg.gloss: “Hoho, if you do not care to, it may as well be I!”

p.seg: hêy , nimisê , wî-matwê-nôtiskwêwêw êkwah kinâpêm ! itwêyiwa otânisah awa . “Oh, but sister, it says your husband is going courting!” said that man's daughter.
hâ , ntohtamwak , ê-pêkopayicik . They listened to it, waking up.
êkwah awa itohtêw awa nâpêsis . Then that boy went there.
êkwah awa kotak kâ-kiyâmêwisit namwâc êkwah waskawimakaniyiw wîpisis ; ayis nipâw ; Then the arrow of the other boy, the one who was bashful, did not move at all, for he slept;
awa pikoh k-ôsâmicônisit ka-waskawîmakaniyik wîpisis . only the prattler's arrow bobbed up and down.
êkwah ntawi-nôtiskwêwêw . Then he went courting.

êh-pîhtokêt ,
mahtih wasaskotênah ! itwêw awa okimâw awa otânisah . When he entered the lodge, “Make the fire bright!” said the chief's daughter.
pôt ôhi awâsisah êh-kitâpamikot , wîst êh-kitâpamât , kâ-wîh-pâhpiyit . Then, when she behold the child looking at her, and in turn gazed at him, he smiled at her.
âstawinah ! itwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . “Put out the fire!” said the young woman.
âstawinamwân ôm îskotêw . The fire was put out for her.
êkosi kawisimôw . [no translation]
nîsôhkwâmiwak , kotakah iskwêwah êh-otinât . [no translation]
âcimostawêw êh-mîsihtâcik . He told her of how they had acquired a supply of meat.

seg.q: ôhih k-êhtahtikih mîkiwâhpah kahkiyaw omatokâhpiwâhk têsipicikanah sâ-sâkaskinêwah .
seg.gloss: “Of as many tents as are in their camp-site, all the drying-scaffolds are filled.
I shall come back here.

seg.q: êkospi kôhtâwiy kika-wîhtamowâw , kîh-pîhtokêyâni ; êkospi ka-kiskêyihtênâwâw .
seg.gloss: When I do so, you will tell your father, when I shall have come into the tent; then you will all know about it.
Your father will announce it.
When I come in here again, then you will tell him about it.
Now tomorrow we shall go back;
for my brother has come here with me.
Well, that is all.
I am going back.
It is almost daylight.”

p.seg:
êhag
itik . “Very well,” she answered him.
êkosi wayawîw . Thereupon he went out of the tipi.
pîhtokêw ôhkomah wîkiyihk . He entered his grandmother's lodge.
kawisimôw . He lay down.
mayaw kâ-kawisimot , nêma wîpisis kâmwâtastêyiw . As soon as he had lain down, his arrow off yonder lay at rest.
nipâwak . They slept.
wiyâpaniyik , kîksêpâ kîwêwak . When day broke, early in the morning they went back home.
êw-otâkosiniyik takosinwak wîkiwâhk . Towards evening they arrived at their dwelling.
tântêh ôma ê-kîh-ayâyêk ? itikwak wîwiwâwa . “Where have you been?” their wives asked them.

seg.q: hâ , iyikohk êh-kitâyâhk kâ-kîh-nîmâhiyêk , êkoyikohk k-ôh-pê-kîwêyâhk .
seg.gloss: “Well, far enough to use up the provisions you gave me, and then we came home.

p.seg: osâm apisîs kâ-kîh-nîmâhiyâhk , itêwak . You gave us too little food for the way,” they told him.
êkos êh-wâpaniyik , nâcipahâw awa osîmimâw . So when the next day came, the younger one drove buffalo.
êkosi mihcêt pêsiwêw mostoswah . He brought many buffalo.
kîhtwâm êh-wâpaniyik , âsay mîna nitotamâw kita-nîmâcik ; On the next day after that he again asked for provisions;
êkwah itah êh-miywâsik mîciwin miyâwak mistahi . and they were given much of the very best food.
êkosi kîksêpâ wayawîwak . Then early they went out of the tent.
mayaw êh-âkawêwêcik , ohpîwak . As soon as they were behind a rise in the land, they flew up.
pêyakwan ; êw-otâkosiniyik , takosinwak . It was as before; in the evening they arrived.
êkosi pîhtokêwak ôhkomiwâwa wîkiyihk . They went into their grandmother's lodge.
êkwah sêmâk miyikwak ôhkomiwâwa ta-nipâkêcik . This time at once their grandmother gave them bedding.
mayaw ê-tipiskâyik miyêwak ôhkomiwâwa . As soon as night had fallen they gave it to their grandmother.

seg.gloss: “Keep these good victuals, grandmother.

p.seg: wâpahki kîksêpâ ntomimâhkan aw ôkimâw otânisah : itâp ta-pêy-itohtêw , itêw ôhkomah . Early tomorrow morning call the chief's daughter: she is to come here,” he told his grandmother.
nêtê wîkiwâhk ntohtawâw , wîpisisihk ohci . Off yonder where they dwelt he was heard through his arrow.
êkw anih wâh-owîskwiyin , nimisê ! itimâwa otânisa . “So now you are to have a fellow-wife, big sister!” the man's daughter was told.
êkos êh-tipiskâyik , ntawi-nôtiskwêwêw . [no translation]
tâpwê kêkâc ê-wâpaniyik , pê-kîwêw . [no translation]
âsay waniskâyiwa osîma . [no translation]
mistahi kimisi-wanâtahkamikisin ! itik osîma . “You surely do carry on in a dreadful way!” his younger brother said to him.
kiy ôma kâ-misi-wanâtahkamikisiyan ! itêw . “It is you, rather, who go on in a dreadful way!” he answered him.
ntohtawâwak wîpisisiwâhk ohci , ntawâc âskaw êh-pâhpicik ôk îskwêsisak . They were heard through their arrows, and those girls from time to time could not help laughing.

êkw ê-kîsikâk ,
hâ , nôhkô , ntawi-ntom awa oskinîkiskwêw ! Then, when daylight had come, “Now, grandmother, go call that young woman!

seg.gloss: Give her these; she may take them home with her.

p.seg: mâskôc ta-ki-pimâtisiwak ayîsiyiniwak , otihtahkwâwi omatokahpiwâwa , itêw ôhkoma . Perhaps the people will be able to live, if they reach their old camp,” he told his grandmother.

seg.gloss: Then she was called for and invited.
“My grandchild, you are to come to my tent for a bit.”
My grandchild has been bothering me to invite you.
The rest he will tell you.”

p.seg: êhag , itêw . “Very well,” she said to her.
itohtêw . She went there.
êh-pîhtokêt , awin ôhi , kîh-apiyiwa kâ-nôtiskwêwâtikot . When she entered, who was that sitting there, but the one who had courted her!
nahapîstawêw . She sat down by his side.

seg.gloss: “Well, these things are why I have called you here.

p.seg: êkosi mâka pêyakwâw kîh-kapêsihk , êkotah nk-ôh-sipwêhtânân , itêw ; Now, if once they camp on the way, that will be from where we others will depart,” he told her;

seg.q: hâ , êkwah kâ-kî-wîhtamâtân kôhtâwiy kita-wîhtam , ôma kây-itwêyân .
seg.gloss: “Now then, now let your father announce what I have told you, the things I said.

p.seg:
mistahi mîsihtâw kâ-kîh-nakatiht omanâcimâkanah awa , itêw osîma ;
êkosi . A great supply of meat has this one's father-in-law,” he said, referring to his younger brother; “So there.”
hây , êkosi kîwêw aw oskinîkiskwêw . Accordingly, the young woman went home.
ôhtâwiya ntomêw wîkihk ohci . She called her father from her tent.

seg.gloss: “Father, a child has come in here.
[no translation]
Your fellow-old-man who was abandoned has a store of meat.

seg.q: tahtoh k-êhtahtikih matokâhpah , êko-tahtoh ihtahtinwah têsipicikana , wiyâsah êh-akotêkih , itwêw kinahâhkisîm ;
seg.gloss: ‘As many as are the deserted camps. so many are the scaffolds where hang the meats,’ says your son-in-law;
‘Accordingly, so let him announce it,’ he said to me, and that is why I am saying it now.
“Yes, daughter.
And so at last you have that which you begged for, saying, ‘a man.’
Try to live uprightly.

p.seg: kitimâkêyim ana kîskwa , itêw otânisah . Be sympathetic toward your fellow-wife,” he told his daughter.

â , wîhtam :
kika-picinânaw anohc . Then he announced it: “We shall move camp today.

seg.gloss: It is heard that my old friend has a supply of food; it is heard that he has a supply.

p.seg: sôskwâc itah kâ-kîw-ôh-piciyêk , êkotah ka-kapêsinâwâw , itwêw ê-wîhtamawât otayisiyinîma . Without delay you are to camp there whence you have moved camp,” he said, instructing his people.
tâpwê piciwak kahkiyaw . Accordingly, they all moved camp.
itêh êh-kapêsicik , âsay mîna ntawi-nôtiskwêwêw awa . There where they camped for the night, again that one went courting [no translation].
kîksêpâ kîwêw . [no translation]
hâh , takosinwak wîkiwâhk . They arrived at their dwelling.

hâ , mayaw êh-pîhtokêt ,
nîtim , kâhkwêyim kiwîkimâkan ! Then, as soon as he entered, “Sister-in-law, be jealous of your husband!
êyakonih okimâwa otânisiyiwa , êyakonih êh-wîwit , itêw osîma . That chief's daughter, her he has taken to wife,” he said of his younger brother.

seg.gloss: “Nonsense, brother-in-law, it is you, rather, who have taken her to wife.

p.seg: kinitohtâtin ôma tahkih , itik wîtimwa . I have been listening to you all the time,” his sister-in-law told him.

seg.q: ahâw , ntawâsimisitik , kwayâci-pânahamok itah kita-wîkit kimisiwâw , kotak mîna kôhtâwiyiwâw ;
seg.gloss: “Now then, children, make ready by clearing the snow from the place where your elder sister is to stay and your other father;

p.seg: nîswayak kika-pânahênâwâw , itêw . in two places you will clear the snow,” he told them.
tâpwê pâpiciwak . So they moved camp to that place.
sôskwâc kapêsimostawâwak . Without delay they joined them where they camped.
êkoyikohk ati-kâh-kîsopwêyâyiw . By this time the warm weather was coming on.

êkosi êkwah ,
hâw , nisîm , nâcipahâhkan . Then, “Now, brother, drive in some buffalo.

seg.gloss: But watch for him: there is one who hates you.
And there is one who hates me;

p.seg: mâka nika-misawihâw niya , itêw ; but, as for me, I shall defeat him,” he told him;
êkâya wîhkâc sâpo-pimohtêh , piyêsiwatwâwi mostoswak , itêw osîma ; “Never walk through the herd when you bring buffalo,” he told his younger brother;
kiya nîkân nâcipahâhkan , itêw . “Do you first fetch buffalo,” he told him.
êhag , itik . “Yes,” the other answered him.
kîksêpâ sipwêhtêw . Early in the morning he set out.
pêyakwaniyiw êh-tôtahk , êh-mawacihtât mostoso-mêya ; He did as before, collecting buffalo-dung;
pêyakwaniyiw êy-isi-têpwâtât . as before, he whooped at them.
pasikôyiwa . They rose from the ground.
kawipayihôw . He threw himself down.
pê-nîkânohtawêw . He came walking at their head.

mâkohôk ê-sakiskamiyit ôhi mostoswah wataniyah , paspaskiw k-êtâyahk êh-êkotôwiwit awa kâ-kiyâmêwisit . The buffalo pressed him close, stepping on his bird-tail, for the creature which we call the quail, that was the form the bashful one had taken. LB on {paspaskiw}: I here translate {pihyêw}: “partridge,” and {paspaskiw}: “quail,” arbitrarily, for I could not identify the birds; interpreters say partridge for both. The brother here called {paspaskiw} was above named {pihêwokas}.
hâw , ê-wâstahamâmiht ôhi mostoswah , nama kî-sêkopayihôw ; Then, when things were waved to drive on the buffalo, he found no place to go;
sâpo-pimohtêw . he went past the herd.
ê-wih-âta-pakicît , nama kîh-pakicîw . Although he wanted to come to earth, he was not able to.
iyâyaw ê-nîpisîhkopâyik , iyâyaw êkotê ispihâw . Hastily to a clump of willows, hastily he flew up and thither.
kîtahtawê kêkway ispimihk k-ôh-pêtowêkotêyik . All at once something came bearing down with noise through the air.
pimi-tâwikipayihik . it came and struck him.
nama kîh-naskwênik . But it failed to snatch him.
pêyakwanohk wâskâhakociniyiwa . In one place that other creature circled round in the air.

êkwah awa k-ôsâmicônisit ,
êhêhêy , nisîm misi-wanâcihôw ! mahti nka-ntawâpomâw ! itwêw . The the prattler cried, “Dear me, my brother is being destroyed! I must go look after him!”
wayawîw ; ocahcâpiyah otinêw ; êkwah ôhih nîso acosisah otinam . He went out of the tent; he took his bow; and he took those two arrows.
pôt ôhi sakâhk kîh-pimisiniyiwa osîma . There in the grove he saw his brother lying.
êy-otihtât , êkotah kisiwâk akosiyiwa piponasiwa . When he reached him, close by a winter-hawk was hanging in the air.

seg.q: hêy ! pêyakwan ôma kây-isinâkosiyin , êkosi kik-êsinâkosin .
seg.gloss: “Hey! Exactly as now you appear, even so shall be your bodily form.

seg.q: osâm ayîsiyiniwak wîcêwatwâwi , tahk âyiwâk kika-tôtên .
seg.gloss: [no translation] you would always transgress.

p.seg: ncawâc êkosi pikoh kik-êsi-mîcison , ôma kâ-tôtaman ! itêw . You will have to get your food always in the way of this which now you have done!” he said to it.
nama kih-kwêskimôw ; nama kîh-ayisiyiniwiw . It could not change its form; it could not turn back into human shape.

êwakoni
kipakwâtik
kây-itiht awa kâ-nipahiht paspaskiw . It was the one of whom the quail who was slain had been told, “He hates you.”
êkwah osîma . Now for his brother.

ispâhkêw wîpisis ; kotak mîna ê-ispâhkêt , pasikôyiwa osîma ; pimâcihêw . He shot an arrow into the air; when he had shot the second one as well, his brother rose to his feet; he had restored him to life.
pôtih ayisiyiniwah wâpamêw , êh-akosiyit pîhtokahânihk . he saw a man sitting up on the hurdles of the enclosure.
otihtimanâhtanah kikiskawêyiwa . He wore a bracelet on his arm.
nîhcipayihôw aw k-ôsâmicônisit , êh-ntonahk môhkomânitosâpisk . The prattler descended to earth and began to look for a flint arrow-head.

seg.gloss: “Oho! I prized it, Glutton, my flint arrow-head!”

p.seg: kitâpamêw ; mihkôwiyiw om ôcihciy . He looked at him; his hand was bloody.
ômisi tôtam . He did like this.

seg.gloss: “It must be you, Glutton!”

p.seg: êh-itât , kontah apsi-kâhkâkîsa kâ-moskôwêpahwât oskisikoyihk . As he said so to him, it was a magpie that he struck full in the face.

seg.gloss: “Here needs you will beg from human men!
You will not be able to change your form!

p.seg: kâsiyâpih ; kika-wâpin anima ! itêw . Wipe your face, you will have sight!” he said to it.
nama kîh-kwêskimôw . It could not change its form.
sakâhk kik-ôhtâpanihon ! itêw . “In the woods you will get your sustenance!” he told it.
êh-itiht awa , ohpihâw ; kont îtê ispihâw . When it was told thus, it flew up; it flew somewhere aloft.
nama kîh-ayisiyiniwiw kâwih . It was unable to take on human form again.

seg.gloss: “Let us needs both go tomorrow;

p.seg: nâcipahâhkahk , itwêw awa k-ôsâmicônisit , let us drive buffalo,” said the prattler,
êkotah kit-ôyasôwâtâyahkok ôki ayîsiyiniwak , itêw osîma ; “Then let us plan for these people,” he said to his younger brother;

seg.gloss: “For it will not go well --
mortal men are to be born here on earth,

p.seg: - ta-sîkawistamôwâyahkok ôm âskiy , itêw osîma . and we must clear this earth for them,” he told his brother.
êhag , itik . “Yes,” the latter answered him.
êkwah nîsiwak , êh-wâpaniyik , êh-nâcipahâcik . Then both went, the next morning, to drive buffalo.
hâ , nêtê mostoswah osîhêwak ; So off yonder they made buffalo;
kîwêhtahêwak mistahi mihcêt , cikawâsis êkwah ê-pîhtokêpayiyit . and they brought back with them a vast number, but only a few went into the corral.
awa pihêw mêstakayitâsah kikitâsêw ; awa paspaskiw mêstakayitâsah kikitâsêw . The Partridge wore breeches of hair, and the Quail wore breeches of hair.
êkwah mohyâpitasêkôwak . And they wore their clothes with the fur turned in.
mistahi miyosiwak . They looked most handsome.
nîsokâpawiwak , ê-mêscihâcik ôhi mostoswah . They stood together, the two as they slew all the buffalo.
âtiht ayîsiyiniwak êh-mêkwâ-wiyinihtâkêwiht , pê-ntaw-asamâwak mînsâpoy . While some of the people cleaned the game, others came to give them berry-water to drink.

seg.q: hâw , ayîsiyinîtik , ncawâc kiyawâw nanâtohk kik-êtôwiwinâwâw .
seg.gloss: “Now then, people, you will have to turn into various forms.
As many as are the beasts, as such you will find your sustenance.

seg.q: kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw kika-sâkôcihikowâw , ohpikicih ôtê nîkân .
seg.gloss: Every mortal man will overcome you, when off in the future he grows forth into life.

seg.q: êkwah niyah ôtêh tawâyihk nik-âyân , kâ-nisticik acahkosak .
seg.gloss: But as for me, there in middle space I shall be, where are three stars.
Forever I shall live.

seg.q: êkwah awa nisîm , ôtêh ta-nîsiwak acahkosak , kâkikê ta-pimâtisit nisîm .
seg.gloss: And as for this my younger brother, there shall be twain stars, and forever shall my brother live.

seg.q: osâm wiyasiwêw kôhtâwiyinaw ta-sîkawiyahk , askîhk kit-ôhpikihitot ayîsiyiniw .
seg.gloss: For our Father has planned that we shall make way for mortal man to grow forth here on this earth.”

p.seg: êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . This is as far as this sacred story goes.
